label.text: Which energy transformation is most likely to occur when the foam absorbs sound?
sound energy to heat energy
sound energy to electrical energy
sound energy to gravitational potential energy
sound energy to elastic potential energy
Porous Materials
Sound deadening is the process of reducing the intensity of sound emitted by machines using sound insulationmaterials.

Mostly, polymer(plastic) foams are used for sound deadening. Other materials, such as foams made of metal, can beused. For example, metal foams are placed inside aircraft engines to reduce the sound emitted.
To create metal foam, researchers coat a polymer foam with a metal alloy then burn away the polymer.
This simulation models the amount of noise produced by an aircraft engine with metal foam sound deadening. Itcalculates the sound intensity with different number of pores and pore sizes in the foam.
Pore diameter (μm)
Number of pores
Low
Medium
High
Initial sound intensity (W/m2)
Final sound intensity (W/m2)
Follow these steps to see how the simulation works:
Move the slider for Pore diameter.
Move the slider for Number of pores.
If you wish to change the sound emitted from the aircraft engine before it travels through the foam, move the slider for Initial sound intensity.
Click the 'run' button to see the results. The results will also display in the table.
Describe two advantages of using a simulation to determine the optimal pore size and number of pores for sound absorbing.

text.em: Run the simulation to collect data to answer the question below.

label.text: Which one of these describes the effect of increasing the pore diameter of the material on the final sound intensity?
intensity increases
intensity decreases
intensity stays the same

text.em: Run the simulation to collect data to answer the question below.

label.text: Investigate the effect of metal foam with a pore diameter of 300 µm on a sound with an intial density of 100 W/m2.
What is the best estimate of the sound's final intensity when the number of pores are changed as indicated?
10 W/m2 for a low number of pores
30 W/m2 for a medium number of pores
50 W/m2 for a high number of pores
70 W/m2 for a high number of pores

text.em: Run the simulation to collect data to answer the question below.

label.text: The sound absorbing coefficient determines how much sound a material will absorb. The higher the coefficient, the greater the proportion of sound absorbed.
For example, a material with a particular pore diameter and number of pores allows 20% of the initial sound to be transmitted, so it’s absorbing coefficient will be 80%.
Which graph shows the most likely effect of initial sound intensity on the absorbing coefficient of a material?
coefficient
initial sound intensity
